text.p: These are some of the main stories in Sofia newspapers today. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
-- Bulgaria's President Petar Stoyanov said he had asked for an official meeting with Russia's President Boris Yeltsin to clarify Bulgaria's position on the eastward expansion of NATO.
-- Bulgaria's Trade and Industrial Chamber (BTIC) has proposed to the interim cabinet to ban street trade in foods, BTIC chairman Bozhidar Bozhinov said. @

-- Bulgaria's Black Sea resort Albena is expected to invest some $5 million in reconstruction and development of its facilities by the beginning of May, Albena's executive director Krassimir Stanev said.

-- Bulgaria's Trade minister Daniela Bobeva left for Brussels to attend a meeting on standartisation of trade ministers from the European Union countries and EU associate members, private Balkan news agency said.
-- Bulgaria's President Petar Stoyanov discussed speeding up privatisation in the country with the visiting chairman of the global investment firm Goldman Sachs Peter Sutherland. @
-- The Russian Rosneft oil company is interested in buying a stake in Bulgaria's biggest oil refinery Neftochim, Rosneft's vice president Favoris Davletyarov said.
-- Bulgaria is expected to start using in the next few weeks a 100 million mark commodity credit, extended by Germany in 1992, Agriculture minister Roumen Hristov said.

-- Introduction of a currency board system is part of the measures to restore confidence in Bulgaria and statements to the contrary could have a destasbilising effect, Bulgaria's Union of Democratic Forces leader Ivan Kostov said.
-- Bulgaria's year-on-year inflation in February was 1,839 percent, National Statistics Institute figures showed.
-- Bulgaria's Privatisation Agency said it had sold a 80 percent stake of bankrupt electronic components maker Mikroelektronika to Sofia-registered Secury Mark for $704,870. @

-- Thirty-two percent of Bulgarians trust the European Union and another 27 percent have a conditional confidence in the EU, Bulgaria's Noema polling agency said. -- Sofia Newsroom, (++359-2) 981 8569
